reviews.title: Reflections And Memories Of Hardship And Challenging Times of 1847
text: This memorial to the famine in Ireland in 1847 due to the disease that devastated the potato crop made immigration the difficult choice…Canada was one of the selected destinations and this Irish Park features a beautiful location along the waterfront on Eireann Quay…this commemoration features 5 bronze statues reflecting the despair and isolation the Irish Immigrants experienced and there is a large limestone wall built with imported Kilkenny limestone that has the names of 675 Irish migrants who died in 1847 on this tragic passage to Canada..this park reflects a connection with the past and a hope for the future..

reviews.title: Small park with great views of Toronto Skyline
text: I'm not sure if the park really pays homage to the Irish people who came to Canada, but it is a nice little park to get some fantastic views of the Toronto Skyline. Not the best views, but for a short ride from Union Station, it's nice.
Some of the statues might be frightening looking to young children.

reviews.title: A must see!
text: Beautiful exhibit, stunning sculptures, but in an oddly out of the way place, until you understand why it is where it is.  Better to access from Queen's Quay than the foot of Bathurst St. as the approach is much more appealing and you face the sculptures when you get down to the bottom at the lake. Some of the names of those that perished are engraved on the limestone sculpture of a ship at the bottom end of the memorial, the limestone all coming from Kilkenny.  Very peaceful and serene little park, with a history that is so sad, yet so filled with hope for those that arrived in Canada.

reviews.title: Sunset Strip
text: Ireland Park is the best place to photograph and enjoy views of the CN Tower close-up & to watch float planes leaving from Billy Bishop airport. There are picnic tables and benches, stretching from Toronto School to the park’s statuary. Guirei Japanese restaurant, across from Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre on Leckie Way and Queens Quay, is an option for packed sushi or Korean (cooked) gimbap rolls. The parkside Waterfront Centre has public washrooms and is open daily (until 9 pm weekdays/ 5 pm weekends). Pay parking is not far away at 75 Queens Wharf, or a block further up at 150 Dan Leckie Way aside the Tim Horton’s. We crossed the footbridge over the GO trains at Portland and Front St, facing Concord City Place, and strolled to Waterfront before sunset. You can give yourself 1-2 hours to cycle around or experience the city scene there. For a quick peek, views of the CN Tower were also nice at the War of 1812 Monument park on Wellington St West, closer to the clubs/restaurant strip. Both parks offer visitors an opportunity to appreciate historical monuments and the heritage of the city, especially in fine weather.

reviews.title: Zombies & Irish Immigrants
text: The first words I spoke upon seeing this monstrosity was WHAT THE HELL! It is insulting to the Irish immigrants (which are my ancestors). They look like zombies and are disgusting. Yes, they came to Canada to escape a famine, but come on, it could have been done so much better. We moved past this mess to read the names of those that came. We were looking for ancestor names but soon found out that wasn't going to happen. Someone took the time to put those names up, but nobody can read them as they are on slaps of stone so close together you can't read them. SO DISAPPOINTING! Shame on whoever thought this was appropriate to my ancestors.

reviews.title: Moving Tribute to our Irish Ancestors Forced Here by the Great Irish Famine
text: A stark reminder of the first huge wave of refugees to hit Toronto then a city of 20,000. Starved out of Ireland by the British over 38,000 of them arrived in the city in 1847. 5 bronze statues of the wretches who made it to this shore are tucked into this very out of the way little parkette on Lake Ontario at the bottom of Bathurst.

reviews.title: A hidden gem
text: What a delightful find! As I walked the waterfront, I strolled behind the old Malt stacks and found Ireland Park by Ireland Park Foundation Wonderful sculptures that are almost hidden from the city.   I found myself lingering at each sculpture, making an emotional connection. The sculptures highlights the story of the Irish immigrants that came to  Canada. Despite the location, it is worth a visit to take in these hidden gems

reviews.title: Beautiful and sad tribute to the Great Irish Famine of 1845-1849
text: The Ireland park, located on Toronto waterfront, slightly over 20 minutes' walk to the west of CN Tower, is a poignant tribute to the victims of the terrible Great Famine, that in the course of 4 years, from 1845 to 1849, ravaged Ireland and resulted in 1 million deaths and mass immigration from the country.
In 1847, over 30,000 Irish immigrants came to the shores of Toronto, back then a city of 20,000 residents. Over 1,000 men, women, and children succumbed to the illnesses.
The tragic events are commemorated in the group of sculptures by the world renowned Irish artist Rowan Gillespie.
The park is quite small; 10 to 15 minutes is enough to tour the Ireland Park.

reviews.title: My number one in Toronto
text: Tucked away behind three huge disused silos, this monument has even more poignancy as a disregarded monument raised to a disregarded people.
The statuary called to my heart. Only in Kilmainham goal have I experienced such a tug of the historical tragedy of Ireland.

reviews.title: We came across this by accident
text: We came across this park by accident while on the way to the Island Airport. It was a beautiful day but the park is very sad. The sculptures need a good cleaning. The grass  area is recovering from a Canadian winter but unfortunately too many dog owners don't know the meaning of "stoop and scoop". The black wall is supposed to be a tribute, it's actually very depressing. And the round glass "thing" looks totally out of place. The location (next to the disused Canada Malting Silos) and hidden from the airport building by a fence) means not many people will see it unless they go snooping around.
I'm half Irish - and proud it. But very disappointed about this park - location is wrong, it's plain ugly and dwarfed by something even uglier. Why isn't it near Nathan Phillips Square????

reviews.title: Who ever knew this park existed? So cute
text: What a great little park tucked away from traffic. We only found out about it because it was St. Patrick's Day and I was looking for something interesting to do. Actually, we had a hard time finding it. It was very disappointing to find the small grass area covered in dog poop. I guess people think that if no one sees them leaving their dog poop, it doesn't matter?? Sad and embarrassing that people are not picking up after their dogs at such a cute and small park where people are coming from all over to check out. Very disrespectful!

reviews.title: Memory of a Tragic History
text: Ireland Park is a modest but compelling memorial of the tragic history of the mid-nineteenth century Irish famine that pushed massive numbers of impoverished Irish to leave their home country and flee to North America and elsewhere. Many died on the way or after arriving.
Part of the power of the memorial is its starkness and simplicity.
The Ireland Park Foundation also has a web site.

The memorial is just east of Billy Bishop Airport in Toronto Harbour at the foot of Bathurst Street. The address given above is incorrect. It is very easy to overlook Ireland Park, as I only discovered it after a decade of travelling through this airport. I visited on an overcast January afternoon that seemed to add to the feeling of sombreness that the Park induces.
The memorial area is dwarfed by abandoned industrial silos surrounded by a chain link fence.
It consists of several pieces of stonework, and stone with a plaque commemorating the 2007 inaugural of the memorial.

The focal point though is a series of compelling statues of tragic impoverished and suffering Irish men and women. These statues are very moving. The photographs I posted do not do justice to the statues because of the low light. There is a parallel and larger set of statues in Dublin on the north bank of the River Liffey, if you have a chance to visit there.
It would be nice if the memorial could be enhanced by some sort of border that would set it off from the surrounding area.

This is a powerful remembrance of a terrible event that has shaped modern Ireland, and Canada. Especially for someone with Irish heritage, it invites contemplation and reflection on a brutal chapter of history.

reviews.title: Moving experience
text: This is very reminiscent of a famine memorial in Dublin, Ireland and visited on a recommendation from a local colleague. It is very moving and poignant.

reviews.title: 'Eerie Éireann Quay'
text: It's a shame that one has to be Irish, studied the Irish culture, or visited Ireland to learn about the devastating Irish famine of 1847.

Located at the foot of Bathurst Street and Queens Quay adjoining the Canada Malting Silos is a very haunting display of five life size bronze statues depicting the Irish immigrants that fled from Ireland.

Dublin, Ireland has a similar display of statues as a memorial to the Irish immigrants who fled Ireland for a better life. All of them hungry, thin, sick, but still reaching out hoping for a new life in Toronto. There is a  hungry pregnant woman clenching her unborn child, a young child still clinging to hope, and one of the statues is dead, their lifeless body sprawled onto the ground.
Its heartbreaking!

Today was a real eye opener of the suffering and devastation these Irish immigrants endured having to leave their beloved Ireland, in hopes of a better life whilst making the difficult journey across the Atlantic onto the shores of Toronto. Arriving on the 'coffin' ships starving, too weak and many sick with typhoid, some died at sea but many died upon arrival. Others had to be put in a quarantined complex that was actually situated at King and John street, 170 years ago.
The day we chose to visit this memorial was very cold and the lake was very choppy. It added to the already eerie feeling we got just from being at the memorial site.
The street name the Irish memorial is on is called Éireann Quay.

Huge boulders of black Irish limestone was shipped from Kilkenny, and houses the names of some but not all of the 38 thousands of women, men and children immigrants that died for a new beginning in Toronto. The names of those identified carved into the slabs of the black Irish stones.
Ireland Park is a touching reminder of the 1847 Irish famine, and the memorial on Éireann Quay shares a direct link with the memorial found in Dublin.
You don't have to be Irish to see this. It's part of our Canadian history. 🇮🇪 🇨🇦

reviews.title: Touching little park
text: The area is currently under construction so there is a chain link fence blocking you from the southern lakeside area.
But it is an interesting place nonetheless, I do not think many people know about it. The statues are riveting and horrifying at the same time.
You can get a nice view of the CN Tower, and it's quiet and peaceful. Lots of sitting areas as well, due to a multitude of benches.

reviews.title: Historically Significant And Largely Overlooked
text: Ireland Park sits at the foot of Bathurst Street in Toronto near the site of the make-shift quarantine complex that was set up to house the Irish escaping the horrors of the Coffin Ships they boarded to escape the Great Hunger. Many did not survive the crossing of the Atlantic. Many more died of disease and malnutrition right near this park. The park has sculptures of the Irish who made (or almost survived) the crossing. The artist is the same who did the Departure statues that you can see riverside in Dublin, Ireland. The Arrival statues are equally moving. Also at the park are giant slabs of stone from Ireland which has the names of the Irish carved in the small openings between the giant rocks. Ireland Park is right near the ferry/tunnel to the Toronto Island Airport - a very short walk indeed and worth the time.

reviews.title: Nice little park
text: It's worth a visit if you're already in the area (e.g. walking along Queens Quay), but the park itself is quite small, and during my visit what looked like interactive screens which I'm assuming would tell you a little bit more about the memorial were all out of service.
Still, you'll get a good vantage point of the CN Tower and the harbour front, as well as prime spot to see the Porter planes landing and taking off from the Billy Bishop Airport.

reviews.title: Waterfront Destination
text: This is a lovely and moving memorial to Irish immigrants to Toronto.  It's worth a walk right out to the water's edge, overlooking the island airport and the harbour.  The path goes from Queens Quay along the east side of the community center/school towards the water.  The sculptured figures are life size and realistic, placed in the outdoors.  Your visit need not be long, but the impression it makes will last.

reviews.title: Ireland Park, Toronto
text: This small park is open between waterfront construction periods. A recent visit showed that some elements are not operating, e.g. an explanatory introduction and the book of names. Hence the "average" rating. However, the setting and the sculptures are definitely worth viewing. The "arrival" sculptures here are a reflection of the "departure" sculptures in Dublin, Ireland. In 1847 Toronto received a massive immigration of starving and sick people from Ireland that almost overwhelmed the city. Situated on the harbour near the old Lake Ontario shoreline (Queens Quay and Bathurst Street), the park is close to where the hospital sheds were erected and the necessary burial ground. "Death or Canada" is the name of a two-part documentary about this extraordinary migration. The website tells you a little more of the history: http://www.irelandparkfoundation.com/index.php.
